ff53c3a0-988a-40a4-b5f9-e5a4b634f5eb.text:
Choose one or both —
• Return target Human creature card from your graveyard to your hand.
• Return target non-Human creature card from your graveyard to your hand.

ff8fae94-3a34-4bc6-aaa2-7ab7d2e2d0dd.name: Flare
ff8fae94-3a34-4bc6-aaa2-7ab7d2e2d0dd.text:
Flare deals 1 damage to any target.
Draw a card at the beginning of the next turn's upkeep.

ff9f4bfe-1585-4eaa-943c-1e85ed79a820.name: Disempower
ff9f4bfe-1585-4eaa-943c-1e85ed79a820.text: Put target artifact or enchantment on top of its owner's library.

ffa93a79-7a10-4331-91de-eabbc4fee17e.name: Barishi
ffa93a79-7a10-4331-91de-eabbc4fee17e.text: When Barishi dies, exile Barishi, then shuffle all creature cards from your graveyard into your library.

ffc3beec-6485-428d-a251-fa0bc21263a5.name: Sinister Concoction
ffc3beec-6485-428d-a251-fa0bc21263a5.text: {B}, Pay 1 life, Put the top card of your library into your graveyard, Discard a card, Sacrifice Sinister Concoction: Destroy target creature.

ffc56a2e-f3bd-493b-9b7b-5f04fad69382.name: Angelic Captain
ffc56a2e-f3bd-493b-9b7b-5f04fad69382.text:
Flying
Whenever Angelic Captain attacks, it gets +1/+1 until end of turn for each other attacking Ally.

ffd3c928-af42-4d69-8d22-a4c72f93b1c7.name: Harvest Hand // Scrounged Scythe

ffe25048-0bd4-49b5-aecb-2b1b57fb8d8b.name: Borderland Ranger
ffe25048-0bd4-49b5-aecb-2b1b57fb8d8b.text: When Borderland Ranger enters the battlefield, you may search your library for a basic land card, reveal it, and put it into your hand. If you do, shuffle your library.

cards.flavor: "Justice isn't done until undeath is undone."
"Though Innistrad is not cleansed of evil, we finally have cause to rejoice."
"I understand your fears. I pity your doubts. I absolve you of both."
"The air stirred as if fanned by angels' wings, and the enemy was turned aside." —Tales of Ikarov the Voyager
The sky rang with the cries of armored seraphs, and the darkness made a tactical retreat.
A golden helix streaked skyward from the Helvault. A thunderous explosion shattered the silver monolith and Avacyn emerged, free from her prison at last.
"Mix the mortar with holy wards, or blood will run in the streets." —Vadvar, Thraben stonewright
Grace is a gift, never a reward.
Avacyn's holy warriors kept hope alive in her darkest hours. Now they will carry that hope across Innistrad.
"Evil will soon be vanquished. What Innistrad most needs now is healing."
"Even storm clouds bow to worship Avacyn." —Elder Rimheit
"Wear her symbol with honor, a sign of faith upheld and honest deeds bravely done."
No longer the village pariah. No longer taunted and shamed. Sigrun was finally free.
Once vampires are disarmed, they're given wooden swords and forced to assist in the training of Midnight Duelists.
Gisela cornered the murderous demon among the graves of the dead villagers. "A fitting end," she murmured as she raised her sword.
"By Avacyn's decree, we shall cleanse these relics of their demonic past."
"You have done your best. I give you leave to rest."
"I'd slog through a thousand swamps to help one soul find rest."
"One faith, but many hands in victory."
The Host sings of Avacyn's return without a single verse about its own suffering.
Her eyes see through the rotting flesh and glimpse a soul in agony, begging for the Blessed Sleep.
The finest maneuvers take place in three dimensions.
Avacyn's return did not rid him of his desire for revenge.
"I cultivated my faith in Avacyn despite meager returns. Now my faith is repaid."
Wails and whispers are the only weapons she has left.
Inquisitors are taught scripture, philosophy, and the fine art of sharpening an axe.
"Monsters will no longer find safety under the mists of Morkrut!" —Bruna, Light of Alabaster
She parts the clouds so sunlight can reach even the darkest lairs and duskiest tombs.
"Once more into Devil's Breach, soldiers. I want another devil tail for my collection."
Her horn is heard across Innistrad, lifting the hearts of the righteous.
"Cower, fiend. The night is yours no longer."
Side effects may include foul odors, scalding steam, and spontaneous nonexistence.
"I knew I'd find a use for all that newt spittle!"
Debates between wizards are never purely academic.
"I am no mere ship's captain. The north wind is my accomplice. The tide is my first mate."
One breath of the geist turns veins to rivers of ice and freezes hearts midbeat.
It's hard to argue with a force made of divine will.
Stray into the Morkrut and it may rise to claim you.
Long thought to be extinct, flocks of gryffs reappeared with Avacyn's return.
The choices of the living will tether them in death.
The first spell taught to young mages, it has spared the lives of many whose hands are too small to hold a sword.
Angels and demons aren't the only ones listening to your prayers.
"There's no such thing as 'impenetrable.'"
Sometimes it's useful to take a break from existence.
"Geists wish to make themselves known. I'm merely the vessel for their efforts."
"Ghouls smashed the door, but I heard the call of the gryffs and knew we were saved." —Ekka, shopkeeper of Hanweir
An abomination so violent that the other fiends tremble at the sight of it.
"The cathars have their swords, the inquisitors their axes. I prefer the 'diplomatic' approach." —Terhold, archmage of Drunau
It seeks a tomb that will hold it, a coffin that will give it rest.
"I'm pleased this world has learned the moon affects more than the tides." —Tamiyo, the Moon Sage
"We have emerged triumphant from the darkness. Let our hard-won wisdom guide us to prosperity."
"When you see a raven, head for the hills. It knows when the ghost-tide is headed in." —Sved, fisherman of Nephalia
For some creatures, existing is only a whim.
"My drivers are trustworthy. I removed their tongues myself. Any other questions?"
The student asks how a spell is begun. The master ponders what ends it.
"Soulless demon, you are bound to me. Now we will both dwell in oblivion."
"Don't look into its eyes. It's thinking things no dead thing should think." —Captain Eberhart
"The cathars killed my skaabs down below. Let's see how high their swords can reach." —Ludevic, necro-alchemist
"I see where you're going with that. I don't like it." —Dierk, geistmage
The fear of slipping from the geist's tenuous grip overwhelmed Tolo's joy at his first flight.
Time is a marvelous plaything.
Just as with a peach, the first bite is always the juiciest.
"We must all make sacrifices for the good of Innistrad." —Sorin Markov
"Great art can never be created without great suffering."
"Death not for survival but for vanity and pleasure? This is the decadence I sought to curb." —Sorin Markov
"Which do you deserve, the heft of a femur or the graceful sharpness of a forearm? Decisions, decisions . . ." —Gisa the Mad
Without a mind, it doesn't fear death. Without a soul, it doesn't mind killing.
Those without breath can't complain.
"I guess what they say is true. What doesn't kill you makes you stronger. Or at least stranger." —Captain Eberhart
"Ah, this is a nice life. I can see why you were so desperate to keep it."
Leukin stared at the smoldering angel feathers. "Run!" he screamed to his patrol. "We don't stand a chance!"
Which is the greater folly, summoning the demon or expecting gratitude from it?
Subservience to greater power is the only law in the pit.
The stairs lead down in both directions.
Half a brain rules the mindless.
Some vampires resorted to corpse trading after cathars burned their estates and drove them from their ancestral feeding grounds.
Captain Lewenheart uncovered evidence of a demon cult among the clergy. The Skirsdag never gave him a chance to prove his case.
Even as humans regained the upper hand, some still willingly traded their lives for a chance at immortality.
The body dies in stages. First the skin, then the muscle. The brain is last, much to the victim's dismay.
He roams the streets of Havengul seeking the sick and delirious so that he may cure them of their lives.
"It's a cold, dark journey either way." —Eruth of Lambholt
"Avacyn emerged from the broken Helvault, but her freedom came at a price—him." —Thalia, Knight-Cathar
"He is judge, jury, and executioner because he killed them all." —Bishop Cawle of Elgaud
"Damned crows and their endless squawking . . . blocks out the voices in my head . . ." —Hermit of Hanne Hall
"I have seen a hundred mortal families rise and fall. I shall outlast a thousand more." —Olivia Voldaren
Even after Hanweir was saved, Gisa's lost ghouls would shamble through, still following the twisted orders of their imprisoned master.
"I come looking for demons and I find a plane full of angels. I hate angels." —Liliana Vess
"Who am I to break up a family?" —Gisa the Mad
"No matter how far we push into Stensia, undeath will always remain in these lands." —Terhold, archmage of Drunau
"His mind is feeble. Feed him to the bats."
An undead snake doesn't bite in self-defense. It hungers as any zombie, never sated.
After the zombie attack, crops withered on the vine, and the thriving village became a ghost town almost overnight.
"Have you ever cornered a wounded vampire? That's a walk in the cathedral garden in comparison." —Tristen, Cathar Marshal
It rises with the fall of darkness, seeking souls to extinguish.
Vowing to free the souls of her children, Kastinne followed the tormentors into the ghastly network of caves below Stensia.
"I've seen corpses prettier than you, beastmage." —Liliana Vess
Heartless killer in life, brainless killer in death.
Agreements with demons seldom end at the grave.
"Barbarians! They burned my favorite chair! We'll kill them all!" —Anje Falkenrath
Swifter than an angel, crueler than a demon, and relentless as a ghoul.
After the destruction of the Helvault, fearful mobs soon became fearless battalions.
"A church is just wood and walls. A congregation is the faithful praising the angels." —Kolman, elder of Gatstaf
"C'mon friend, take a turn tossing the knucklebones. What've you got to lose?" —Tobias, trader of Erdwal
"To truly defeat a skaberen, you must destroy not the monster but the lab." —Rem Karolus, Blade of the Inquisitors
Hours after the Helvault opened, his powers returned twice as strong as before.
"I'll put my sword down only to die. And I don't plan on doing that today."
"Well, how could I know they'd explode?" —Gregel, township militia
"Fire will eventually destroy a zombie, but a fiery zombie destroys a lot of other things first." —Rem Karolus, Blade of the Inquisitors
"That slowly decreasing pulse—that's the beat I waltz to."
Discontent is a powerful weapon in the hands of a mob.
Unhappy with the creation of the wolfir, Rorica broke with her order and led a crusade against the "reformed werewolves."
"Undead flesh is dry and papery. A single spark and 'poof.' No more ghoul."
"There's no heron in the moon! It's a shrew, a five-legged shrew, with a voice like whispering thunder!"
As peace returned to Thraben, some cathars made the mistake of letting down their guard.
It descended on Estwald like a sudden storm. Moments later, only ashes and agony remained.
"May the worthy spend an eternity in Blessed Sleep. May the wicked find the peace of oblivion."
Some tried cremating their dead to stop the ghoulcallers. But the dead returned, furious about their fate.
In a wave of spells called the Cursemute, Avacyn cleansed the world with divine fire.
"So the vampires like hot blood, do they? Let's see how they handle ours."
Skirsdag cultists refused to quietly accept Avacyn's ascendancy.
Sometimes it's not for sustenance or to feed the dependence. Sometimes it's just to feel again.
Demons massacre. Devils annoy.
He has nothing left but his resentment.
The dark times left the peasantry ready to fight with whatever weapons were at hand.
"My next aerial design will use less metal." —Hadaken, alchemist of Nephalia
"To survive, we must embrace the savagery we knew in our race's infancy." —Edgar Markov
It's not any fun until someone loses an eye.
It begins as a whisper and ends with the red roar of fire.
"There's only one route from Kessig into Stensia. Unless you come with me."
In the darkest hours, some denied Avacyn. Now the Kessig wilds are their only haven.
Its footsteps of today are the lakes of tomorrow.
After sampling many victims, the spider developed a preference for the undead and their accoutrements.
"It used to eat us trappers. Now it follows us around like some kind of hound dog." —Alena, trapper of Kessig
The abandoned towns on the moors didn't stay empty for long.
"We've tracked Ludevic's monster across four provinces. When it lands, make sure it stays put." —Alena, trapper of Kessig, to Halana of Ulvenwald
"By my power, werewolves shall become the wolfir, our allies in combat against darkness." —Avacyn's Cursemute Decree
"The fiends have fled. Well, good riddance. Nothing I like more than an empty lair."
The haunted blade shattered, and the geist drifted gratefully to the Blessed Sleep.
"I killed one and found bricks and bones in its belly. It had eaten a whole cottage, thatch and all." —Paulin, Somberwald trapper
With Avacyn's return, the flow of life became a tidal wave.
When the forests became havens for evil, the archmages devised new ways to cleanse the wilds.
A hunter's precision and a durkvine's strength are a potent combination.
"You can face any danger when all of nature is on your side."
It's there when a seed sprouts, when gourds ripen on the vines, and when the reapers cut the grains under the Harvest Moon.
Elmut had slaughtered vampires, slain werewolves, and destroyed hordes of zombies. Sadly, he never got over his fear of spiders.
"Can you build a fire? Track a deer? Identify killer trees? Then you'll never survive Kessig without me."
"Rid me of this curse, witch, or die with me." —Garruk Wildspeaker
"Peace will come to Innistrad, but only after all abominations have been dealt with, one by one."

"Where'd the werewolves go? Maybe that got hungry."
—Halana of Ulvenwald
Humans still feared wolves, though no connection between them and the curse of lycanthropy had ever been proved.
"When civilization reaches out its greedy hand, take it off at the wrist." —Garruk Wildspeaker
The geists that dwell in the deep forests of Kessig are as untamable as the woods themselves.
Released from a dark curse and bound to a higher calling.
"I wonder what dwelled in the primordial forests before humans existed." —Elder Rimheit
Great devotion yields great reward.
"Faith can quicken the stones themselves with life." —Writings of Mikaeus
Forged in dark hours from the flame that would not die.
Forged from the rubble of the Helvault.
"Tomorrow wears yesterday's face." —Kordel the Cryptic
"Drain the victim's blood, sell the corpse, and use the soul on guard duty. No muss, no fuss, no problems." —Olivia Voldaren
"Finally, the principles of corpse animation applied to bloodless materials!" —Ludevic, necro-alchemist
"Any fool can open it. But it takes a genius to decipher the blank pages." —Kordel the Cryptic
Words to bless the eye that reads them, telling of a future beyond the reach of fear.
Words no eyes should see, telling of things no sane mind could fathom.
To a demon there is no such thing as restraint.
Wars are not fought on a single front.
Persecuted alchemists fled deep into Kessig's wilds, seeking solitude to continue their ghoulish craft.
A lonely sentinel facing gales, hurricanes, and tides of homicidal spirits.
Its courtyards are lit during every hour of the day so that night may never fall within its walls.
The continent of Bala Ged was ravaged by massive Eldrazi of Ulamog's lineage, its lush jungles and cascading rivers reduced to dust.
"There are some who have lost everyone and everything. They actively seek out the Eldrazi, eager for the smallest measure of vengeance."—Munda, ambush leader
"Over and over it rose. Over and over we fell."—Ganda, Goma Fada deserter
"With precise coordination and enough blood spilled, one can be driven off, even brought down. But two . . . that's a lot of blood."—Munda, ambush leader

"No matter how big your champion, theirs is bigger. No matter how great your numbers, theirs are greater. No matter how voracious your appetite, they are hungrier. That is why the Eldrazi will win."—Kalitas, thrall of Ulamog
It embodies all possible meanings of the word "infinite."
Though Gideon arrived at Sea Gate too late to prevent the massacre, he still had enough time to lead its survivors to relative safety.
"In the dark places of our world, something horrible is growing. I fear our foes may be more numerous than we had imagined."—Nissa Revane
The Eldrazi hunger without limit and consume without pause.
The Eldrazi continue to sweep through the wastes, compounding destruction that already seemed absolute.
"Our people and our very lands disappear as if they never were. We no longer fight for glory, or honor. We battle now for the right to exist."—General Tazri, allied commander
Dust and memory are all that remain in Ulamog's wake.
A force as voracious as time itself.

"Have you ever seen a world fall to its knees? Watch, and learn."
—Ob Nixilis
"No more fear. No more failure. No more death. No more!"
"Zendikar will triumph this day, and our armies will fly with angels."
Though losses run high among the scouts of the Stone Havens, they never flinch from their duty.
"Sea Gate has fallen. Survivors are on the move. Will send another griffin when we find refuge. Stay hidden. Stay safe."—Message from Tars Olan, kor world-gift
The unofficial motto of every expedition house is "ready for anything," a phrase whose significance has been amplified since the emergence of the Eldrazi.
Felidars that make it through their first year of life can easily live to see a hundred years more.
It surveys the withering landscape, waiting for a victory only it can see.
The refuge's defenses allow new recruits to see lesser Eldrazi up close, steeling their stomachs for what's to come.
Mystics of the Stone Havens call upon the spirits of fallen heroes to defend the refuges.
"Suddenly, Gideon was there with us, clearing the way so that we could escape."—The War Diaries
"They seek to break us. Let us show them our strength!"
"For the lands you have lost and the beauty that remains, for freedom and the future, we must hold nothing back!"—Gideon Jura
"The wind in one's hair, the sun on one's back, the joy of open skies . . . the next generation of kor must know this kind of peace."
The high-pitched whirl of a hook is the only battle cry she needs.
"He told us not to worry, and he walked into the cavern. The swirling mass of Eldrazi parted to admit him, then closed in his wake."—Akiri, kor line-slinger
"We came into this world together. We fight for this world together. We'll leave this world together."
Hedron lanterns fend off more than just the darkness.
"Even in the hands of amateurs, Nahiri's hedrons can harm the Eldrazi."—Ugin
Working with his noble mount, he notices every form on the horizon, every scent in the air, every tremor in the earth.
"May your horns get lodged in an Eldrazi's bony face, ornery brute!"—Bruse Tarl, Goma Fada nomad
"We can use their hunger to lead them into danger. If we're already prey, we may as well be bait!"—Yon Basrel, Oran-Rief survivalist
"I can give you strength, but you'll have to bring your own courage."
A few bands of kor sought refuge from the Eldrazi in Zendikar's vast cave networks, relying on their ability to survive in harsh vertical landscapes.
After watching the kor in battle, Gideon understood the difference between working together and working as one.
"These days, soldiers never stick around long enough for a proper healing. They just want me to knit them up so they can hurry back to the fight."
In times of infestation and war, Zendikar favors the blades that strike in unison.
The kor's pride in their independence has given way to a strong sense of community that embraces all of Zendikar.
"The seas are no less imperiled than the dry lands. This fight is mine as much as it is yours."—Kiora, to Gideon Jura
"We are nothing but dust to them—our bodies, our actions, even our words."—Jori En, expedition leader
The touch of an Eldrazi brings life and death in turn.
The wastes spread as quickly as the wind.
If you can see it, it's too late.
Whatever it is searching for, it will stop at nothing to find it.
It didn't do much, but the residents of Sea Gate gave it a wide berth all the same.
Divining the future is easy when you hold the power to sway it.
There are more sights on Zendikar than the eyes can see.
When Emeria's worshippers learned that she was no more than a twisted memory of Emrakul, they abandoned their temples to the god. The deserted shrines now serve as breeding grounds for the mantas.
"She knows every step of this coastline, both above and below the surface, and she has hideouts all along the way. She will get you there."—Jori En, expedition leader
"Quiet now, you dreadful vermin."—Noyan Dar, Tazeem roilmage
"I said we should destroy the Eldrazi. Ugin wanted to return them to stasis. Ugin's arguments were . . . unconvincing."—Jace Beleren
"I can't control its mind—I'm not even sure it has one. But I can dominate its will."
"Quiet the waves? Why would I want to do that?"
Weather on Zendikar is unpredictable—unless you're the one telling it what to do.
Having gone to the trouble of stealing a bident from a god on another world, Kiora was eager to test its capabilities.
"You speak to me of the threat of Ulamog. But do not forget: they came as three."—Ugin, to Jace Beleren
"Do you see? All of Tazeem strains at its tether."—Noyan Dar, Tazeem roilmage
"We returned to the field and found poor Len, every detail of his final moment perfectly cast in that awful dust."—Javad Nasrin, outrider captain
Silence rules Bala Ged, broken only by the skittering of Eldrazi.
As the hand closed, there was first terror, then numbness, and finally nothingness.
It consumes any dreams of victory.
"I watched it pass at a distance. When I looked back to my companions, Najet was dead."—Akiri, kor line-slinger
The Eldrazi rampaged across Zendikar in a tide of chittering, heaving flesh.
"Fear of the unknown can be a wonderfully innocent thing, relatively speaking."—Anowon, the Ruin Sage
"I will secure my revenge on Zendikar one soul at a time."—Ob Nixilis
"Let the vampires join us. In this war, we no longer have the luxury of choosing our comrades."—General Tazri, allied commander
Vastly outnumbered, the Zendikari found creative ways to even the odds.
"Later we will mourn those we have lost. First we must end their suffering."—Drana, Kalastria bloodchief
"Despite their bravado, mortals are fragile. If Zendikar is to endure, its lords must save it."—Drana, Kalastria bloodchief
"Take what solace you can in the knowledge that you will not be here to witness Zendikar's demise."—Ob Nixilis
"I will not live as a slave. If you would be free, then fight alongside me."
When Malakir's surgeons failed, its death-shamans took over.
"It's hard to find their weak points, but I very much enjoy the discovery process."
"Time and again, I have demonstrated my skills as a healer. Why, then, are you so ill at ease?"
"Kalitas may have returned to mindless servitude beneath the Eldrazi, but we say never again."—Drana, Kalastria bloodchief
"They are deadly, and they are loyal. We can spare them a little blood."—Harak, Malakir bloodwitch
Nirkana assassins craft incurable concoctions by mixing basilisk marrow and deathwillow sap with the vital fluids of a dozen other poisonous species.
As the Eldrazi spread, no secret that could give Zendikar's defenders an advantage was considered too dangerous to seek.
For vampires, blood carries more than life. Memories long eroded from the minds of bloodchiefs can be reclaimed from the veins of their sired kin.
"These days, there's no shortage of food for the nulls of Guul Draz."—Drana, Kalastria bloodchief
"Eldrazi? Ha! Try walking through Zulaport at night with your pockets full. Now that's dangerous."
Terrible fury. Excellent aim.
It moves through the tunnels as slowly and surely as the shifting stones.
"Some detours just aren't worth it."—Raff Slugeater, goblin shortcutter
Ulamog's processors trail behind him, converting ruined matter into furious energy.
Some wounds never heal.
"No, don't! Nal, it's me—"
Emrakul has not been seen in months. Though her brood's numbers have dwindled in her absence, each drone is still a deadly threat.
"Whiptails can sense a traveler's footsteps from a great distance. Measuring that distance has been . . . difficult."—Jalun, Affa sentry
With a single act of bravery, she went from expendable to indispensable.
"This world will be ruled by its rightful sovereigns, not these hideous pretenders."
"Come on, you twisted things! Don't you want to get acquainted?"
"The Eldrazi may not be intimidated, but if it boosts the goblins' confidence, I see no reason to discourage it."—Jalun, Affa sentry
Goblins were first to see the potential of hedrons in the fight against the Eldrazi, for the magical stones came ready-made with pointy bits.
After a battle, it breaks the hillsides into manageable pieces to prepare for next time.
"Put a minotaur at the head of an army and suddenly all the soldiers act like they have horns."—Gideon Jura
Everyone who could still lift a weapon had a part in retaking Sea Gate.
The fires of Zendikar are always hungry, and there is much on which they can feed.
"You have a family. Mine died at Sea Gate. You go to yours, and I'll go to mine."
"Zendikar is always angry, though I've never seen that anger so precisely directed."—Nablus, North Hada trapper
Saved from certain death by the kor, he considers himself bound to them by an unbreakable blood oath.
Akoum can make any intruder look small.
To survive imminent doom, it sometimes takes a foolhardy soul who acts first and fears later.
As Ulamog's brood reduces the earth to dust, geopedes burst from their tunnels in search of solid ground.
"As long as we have walked this world, we have known it as a harsh and unforgiving place."—The Invokers' Tales
"Whatever volcanoes dream of, it seems like they always wake up grumpy."—Raff Slugeater, goblin shortcutter
Like a living organism, Zendikar rids itself of infection, and it does so abruptly and ruthlessly.
"A hedron holds magic for a thousand years—or less, if need be."
A blisterpod's corpse is a scion's cradle.
The tenderness of a mother. The pity of a mantis.
Ulamog's progeny swarm the land, draining Zendikar's mana to feed the titan's insatiable hunger.
Every Eldrazi in Ulamog's lineage is an extension of the titan's will.
The battle served as a grim reminder of what a final victory for the Eldrazi would mean.
The Eldrazi don't merely extinguish life—they supplant it.
"They come because I call. They stay because I listen."
The native creatures of Zendikar have adapted to live under rocks and crawl through underbrush in order to avoid the most voracious predators. The Eldrazi have yet to make such adjustments.
"I always thought the great insects of Tazeem were frightening until I saw the Eldrazi. Now I welcome the sight of mantises perched in the treetops."—Ryza, Oran-Rief scout
"Zendikar has given us the weapons to wage war on the appropriate scale."—Najiya, leader of the Tajuru
On Murasa, even the trees grow trees.
"The land is not dead, merely sick. I will nurse it back to health."
"If you're not prepared to fight, you'd best be prepared to die."
"Zendikar will not surrender, and neither can we."
Her connection to the plane restored, Nissa felt the power of Zendikar surge through her.
"The world was not hostile to us—we were beneath its notice, and presented no danger."—The Invokers' Tales
"It might fight the Eldrazi, but don't mistake it for a companion, Gideon. It's not interested in your concept of strength through unity."—Najiya, leader of the Tajuru
The elf's blade carved deep into the Eldrazi drone's fleshy lattices. Without a sound, the drone lost equilibrium and tumbled from the sky.
"This world tires of its long occupation."—Nissa Revane
"If I die, feed me to a shambler. At least that way I'll be doing some good."—Ryza, Oran-Rief scout
Eldrazi are not the leopard's preferred prey, but they are better than no prey at all.
"In my downtime I used to paint the vistas. Now the vistas disappear faster than my downtime."
All of Zendikar's beings sense the upheaval that accompanies the Eldrazi.
"Nissa is not the only one with a deep connection to Zendikar's primal elements."—Kiora
"As long as there is a single shred of life, there is hope."—Nissa Revane
"My mount needs neither reins nor bridle. We both share a common purpose."
"In its time of hardship, all of Zendikar cries out in pain. Are you listening?"
Her rallying cry reaches far beyond the Tajuru elves, inspiring all those who hear it.
It knows nothing of Eldrazi or Planeswalkers, just that there are new intruders in its territory.
"The elements understand better than anyone that actions speak louder than words."—Gideon Jura
The only traces it leaves are silent gusts and prodigious amounts of wreckage.
"While we delay, they're on the move. They will not wait as we bicker. We are losing this war by moments as our goal slips beyond our reach."—Gideon Jura
"Some Eldrazi, their purpose is obvious: suck the life out of the land, birth new Eldrazi. Others aren't so obvious, and those are the ones that make me really nervous."—Chadir the Navigator
As the great scourge passed by, Zendikar shivered, then lay silent.
As the soldiers beneath her raised their voices, the angel spread her wings, their span seeming to cover the sky.
"The taste of freedom is sweeter than blood."
"The land will not wait for the enemy to arrive."—Nissa Revane
"The seedlings scream for us to loose them upon the Eldrazi, and we shall oblige."
They came from all walks of life, from every part of Zendikar, and they returned with one unifying cause.
After many years as a lullmage, Noyan Dar turned his talents from allaying Zendikar's fury to the considerably easier task of rousing it.
"Great steel is born in the hottest forges. Great soldiers are born in war."
"It may be unconventional, but I'll take any steady mount in a storm."
The last hedron slotted into place, locking Ulamog in an infinite loop of binding energy.
"You've begun to understand the hedrons' true purpose," said Ugin. "The Eldrazi can be imprisoned.""And how did that work out last time?" asked Jace.
Also called "pathway stones," hedron shards can immobilize Eldrazi on contact.
Each time it is sent to find a safe haven, it takes longer to return.
Neither subtle nor pretty.
Once, water ran here. Now only dust and ash fall from the clifftops.
"We came to a place where the skin of Zendikar was peeled back and its bones lay bare to the sky."—Greenweaver Mina
The land is dying, but it will not go peacefully.
"When a limb is gangrenous, you cut it off. This is no different."—Greenweaver Mina
The continent of Murasa lies beneath a blanket of dense vegetation, its enormous branches tangled so thickly that some inhabitants never see the ground.
On the volcanic continent of Akoum, bizarre vegetation clusters around gas vents, and jagged mountain peaks rise high into the air.
The Eldrazi may be ruthless, but Zendikar is relentless.
The continent of Ondu is a vast plateau crisscrossed by deep trenches and meandering rivers.
The gods known to the merfolk as Ula, Emeria, and Cosi were nothing more than false memories of a monstrous trinity: the Eldrazi titans Ulamog, Emrakul, and Kozilek.
The continent of Guul Draz is a geothermal swampland reeking of heat and decay.
Young Eldrazi crawl forth from the dust, compelled by a greater will.
On the continent of Tazeem, rushing waters plunge through narrow canyons into mist-cloaked lakes.
Many attempt to speak with nature. Selvala speaks less, and nature answers more.
When immovable object turns to unstoppable force, it's best to just get out of the way.
"Merchants and politicians differ only in name." —Queen Marchesa
"One who ruled willing subjects would need no such protection." —Adriana, Captain of the Guard
"I gladly offer my weapon and my life to the glory of my sovereign."
Before a cause can have supporters, it has to have a voice.
"These halls are sacred. You will be silent."
"Rulers come and go, but my allegiance belongs to the throne."
Within the city walls, Adriana's falcons hunt vermin of all kinds.
The most effective roadways in Paliano aren't roads at all.
Few things are more valuable than time or money—and Leovold has plenty of both.
"Please vote with a clear head and vigilant heart, knowing each voice is meaningful regardless of the outcome." —Ottavio d'Oro, Electoral Committee Speaker of Paliano
Mklthd had always hated crowds . . . and they had always hated him.
For the right price, he'll unlock your path to the throne.
No duelist is without equal in Paliano.
"I did offer them a choice . . ." —Queen Marchesa
"Keeping order is a task too important to relinquish in death." —Abrado, Custodi priest
"Marchesa's poison is delivered by more than daggers." —Adriana, Captain of the Guard
"Those who seize power must have the means to hold it." —Queen Marchesa
"You're done!"
If bribery and intimidation fail, Marchesa turns to her favorite form of bureaucracy.
The whitest robes stain best.
While most in Paliano seek fame through favor, he'll settle for infamy through blood.
Butcher's training, warrior's heart.
"It, uh, fell off a cart?"
"You burn. I'll pillage."
The market is now closed.
"Sit. Fetch. Devastate."
"The dim resort to violence, for which the nimble prepare." —Leovold, emissary of Trest
"The wild are neither your thralls nor your amusement."
Fruits for friends, fists for foes.
"My sword is pledged to the defense of this city, not to the throne or this usurper."
"Hail to the true queen! Long may she reign!"
"I'm sure we can come to an arrangement."
Imitation is the sincerest form of treachery.
A shining symbol of Paliano's true ruler—ambition.
Once a welcoming hub for explorers, Affa became a place of guarded tongues and quick defenses.
The scepter of power is fragile in a calloused hand. —Cho-Arrim saying
He vowed he would never rest until he reached his destination. He doesn't know how right he was.
"I thought the wind was ushering me to my final destination, but it lifted me to my feet and I fought on." —Idrus, war priest of Thune
"May the memory of our fallen heroes ensnare the violent hearts of lesser men." —Great Threshold of Monserkat inscription
Honor the gods of Theros, and they will return the favor.
"Do not let a single shaft loose until my word. And when I give that word, do not leave a single shaft in Eiganjo." —General Takeno
"I'd rather hear the screams of battle than the quiet that follows." —Talara, elvish safewright
Some spirits mourn. Others terrorize.
Mardu archers are trained in Dakla, the way of the bow. They never miss their target, no matter how small, how fast, or how far away.
"It is *not* sad," Radiant chided the lesser angel. "It is right. Every society must have its outcasts."
Like blinking or breathing, responding to an alarm is an involuntary reflex.
Samite healers never mix their pungent elixir with sweetener or tea. The threat of a second dose is enough to get most warriors back on their feet.
Thieves know that a snarl in the night means, "Rob another house."
Farmers typically keep their flocks at thirteen sheep—one to distract the griffins while they take the other twelve to market.
The merfolk call the sky goddess Emeria. The kor call her Kamsa. The two races agree on little except that she offers many blessings to the faithful.
"Cower, fiend. The night is yours no longer."
The sea's reach extends beyond its shores.
"Some merfolk choose to rest their fins in the water. I believe wisdom exists not only where we were born but where we were told not to go."
"That is not the voice of the wind singing on the stones." —Callaphe the mariner
Before signing anything on Grixis, always read the fine print.
First the insult, then the injury.
"There is nothing you can do that I cannot simply deny." —Ertai, wizard adept
"The key to unlocking this puzzle is within you." —Doriel, mentor of Mistral Isle
The first spell taught to young mages, it has spared the lives of many whose hands are too small to hold a sword.
Æther can turn a footprint into a blueprint.
"The cathars have their swords, the inquisitors their axes. I prefer the 'diplomatic' approach." —Terhold, archmage of Drunau
"He's a lot like me, that masterless little kami . . . unimpressed by grandeur and never at a loss for a trick." —Toshiro Umezawa
Merfolk don't always know what they're looking for, but they're certain once they find it.
"Emeria is a pleasant lie, a figment to hide Emrakul's hideous face. I can only hope to uncover a truth that lies deeper still."
"I'd build an entire fortress of them if I could." —Mzali, Lighthouse archmage
"You cannot be an Ojutai monk. They prize wisdom and skill, and you have neither." —Siara, the Dragon's Mouth
Her prophecies amaze her even as she speaks them.
"You aren't invited."
At the academy, "show and tell" too often becomes "run and hide."
"A riddle is nothing more than a trap for small minds, baited with the promise of understanding."
"Mists are carefree. They drift where they will, unencumbered by rocks and river beds." —Thrasios, triton hero
"Don't worry, your death will be as informative as possible." —Gorghul, augur of skulls
When harpies demand a toll to cross through their territory, consider yourself lucky if they permit payment in coin.
Sins that would be too gruesome in the light of day are made more pleasing in the dark of night.
Leukin stared at the smoldering angel feathers. "Run!" he screamed to his patrol. "We don't stand a chance!"
The wise always keep an ear open to the whispers of power.
Some vampires resorted to corpse trading after cathars burned their estates and drove them from their ancestral feeding grounds.
"Here are some bones for you to choke on, dear brother!" —Gisa, to Geralf
The death of a scout can be as informative as a safe return.
Grixis is a world where the only things found in abundance are death and decay. Corpses, whole or in part, are the standard currency among necromancers and demons.
"He is judge, jury, and executioner because he killed them all." —Bishop Cawle of Elgaud
"This is why we don't go out in banewasp weather." —Rannon, Vithian holdout
You will scream out your innermost secrets just to make it stop.
When he reaches for his key ring, you should be running for the exit.
A spark of resistance against a tide of corruption.
Though the executioner did not speak, the villagers got the message.
The earth cannot hold that which magic commands.
"The Kolaghan send them at us. We kill and raise them. They fight the next wave the Kolaghan send. It's a neat little cycle." —Asmala, Silumgar sorcerer

"If fear is the only tool you have left, then you'll never control me." —Xantcha, to Gix

The only livestock that will survive for long in the Smelting District, ember beasts serve many functions—none of them willingly.
After millennia asleep, the Eldrazi had forgotten about Zendikar's fiery temper and dislike of strangers.
"Well, how could I know they'd explode?" —Gregel, township militia

"The best way over the mountain is through."

He wants to watch Ravnica burn, one soul at a time.

It traps an explosion within its stony skin.

—Tales of the Fae
"To the king, to the Circle, and to the realm! And to not dying."

—Legend of the Gilded Knights

"The cruelest monsters inspire the greatest tales. The greatest tales inspire the cruelest hunters."
—Rielle, the Everwise
"There's no roar so mighty that it can't be silenced."

"By halves does youth depart. I remember halves of names, halves of years, halves of myself."
—Ogaro, wandering sage
Hunter and hunted both died thinking they had outwitted the other.

"And then the shadow took living form, and the shadow devoured the man whole—body, mind, and soul."
—*Tales of the Ozolith*
"The big fella sounds hungry. Let's send him to bed without his supper."
Each scorpion's venom is unique, thwarting sanctuary healers' attempts to develop an antidote.

"Yesterday it was flying tigers and crumbling bridges. Who knows what today will bring?"
—Dol, Lavabrink quartermaster

From now until the crystals stop glowing
—Ketria oath meaning "forever"

"With the frequent mutations, predator-prey relationships seem to change every moment. I already like it here."
—Vivien Reid
"I appreciate you not letting me fall to my death in the acid bogs. Now, can you let me down?"
Ears can't hear them. Eyes see too many of them.

"It's just a snake. A many-eyed snake with venom that turns your blood to smoke, but still, just a snake."
—Kinnan, bonder prodigy

"Don't ask me what to do if you miss. They're stingdrakes. Don't miss."
—Orthion, Lavabrink captain

"Ah, we have a critic."
—Orthion, Lavabrink captain
The sound of Vadrok's gigantic wings is ominous. But the true terror is when they fall silent.
The soldier had given up his wealth, his title, even his home, but he had no room for regret. At last, he had saved his friend.

"Let the brutes fight. If they kill each other, we lose no more soldiers today."
—Orthion, Lavabrink captain
The first line of defense, and the last person you want to anger.
From a certain perspective, it's an inspiring story of overcoming obstacles.

"Water and bone tell many tales, but fire is fickle. It would rather consume than reveal."
—Rielle, the Everwise
Fragile, floating Skysail suddenly seemed like an appealingly safe place to live.
The two looked at each other, and neither fled. "I see," the soldier murmured. "We're both just fighting for survival out here, aren't we?"

"Though the road through Raugrin is lined with alarm crystals, some monsters seem to be adapting. We've had raptors feigning attacks on provision caravans, while others try to sneak through the lava curtain."
—Dol, Lavabrink quartermaster
Fortune favors the ferocious.
Lukka's bond provided not only friendship, but also the most powerful weapon in his arsenal.
Some crystals glow in the presence of monsters, forming a convenient warning system. Some monsters have learned to outrun the light.
Lavabrink's boiling moat is a deterrent for most, and a relaxing bath for one.

"It's either terrified or extremely mad at us, definitely one of the two."
—Jonald, mission naturalist
"I always thought wizards were supposed to have owls or one-eyed cats for familiars, but flaming dinosaurs work, too."

"How many claws does a monster have? Exactly one more than you've accounted for."
—Alux, Skysail defender
Danger often lurks in the allure of crystal shards.
Their feeding habits leave them with gizzards full of tumbled gems.

"When monsters walk, the earth knows its place and yields."
—Rielle, the Everwise

"The monster that scares me the most isn't the biggest."
—Taelya, Lavabrink pyromage
Lukka was ordered to kill a threat. He chose to make a friend.
Revenge is a path inevitably walked alone.
An adventure without a companion is hardly an adventure at all.

Laughed at the brushwagg
—Hunters' expression meaning "died unexpectedly"

"They cast wards, thinking it will protect them, but the biggest monsters find a way through."
—Kinnan, bonder prodigy

"I can bring down anything in Zagoth, but for some quarry the ratio of fight to meat is too high."
—Master Hunter Chevill
The Zagoth wetlands are fertilized by centuries of Brokkos's former challenges.

"Turns out the case of the flattened outpost and the cast of the missing kitten *were* related."
—Endris, Drannith magistrate
The Ozolith's appearance spawned a new era of wild mutation on Ikoria. Some creatures hunted different prey, lived in new habitats, and thrived on mutation itself.
It makes molehills out of mountains.
Sometimes the *eludha* is a sacred harmony of souls. Sometimes a bonder grabs some fur and holds on tight.
Poachers use the harvested tongues to snare pests, plumb caves, and scale tall buildings.

"One day I woke up and knew I had nothing left to teach her. So now I ride on her shoulders and follow where she leads."
—Gustin, wildbonder
On Ikoria, sandwurms never lie dormant for too long. In some regions, "no activity" is the greatest sign of danger.
"And I thought *I* had a big sweet tooth." —Gannet, Skysail zoologist
"We share the same nuanced opinion of hunters and military goons: smash them."
"The key to bonding with monsters, no matter their size, is knowing where they like to be scratched."
For safety reasons, the keeping of houseplants within Ikoria's sanctuaries is heavily discouraged.
Life is best taken one step at a time.

"Goriaks are as stubborn and hardy as I'd expect of a large herbivore in a wetland habitat. But I never expected them to have such beautiful voices!"
—Vivien Reid

"The most unexpected weapon a monster can wield is kindness."
—*Tales of the Ozolith*
Scavengers follow in Skysail's shadow, feasting on the carcasses of monsters that attacked the floating city.
"Need a medic! And some stonemasons!" -Wyllon, Drannith merchant

"What's natural on Ikoria continues to delight me."
—VIvien Reid
"And what did we learn? Never taunt a porcuparrot!"

"Your prey is in my custody now. Withdraw."
—Vivien Reid
Nothing returns from the nightmare nests of Indatha unscathed.

"How can you be sure you pierced its heart? Do you even know where its heart is?"
—Trundan, Indatha poacher
Few monsters challenged Narset after they sensed her power.

"I will preserve human life at all costs. I will stand alone against behemoths before I let them touch my city. I will hold the wall."
—Oath of the Coppercoats

"The ground under our feet is a record of every slight against the world, to be avenged at a time of its choosing."
—Gavi, nest warden

"Fear not the behemoth heard from miles away. Fear the stalking felidar, which reveals itself only for the kill."
—Rielle, the Everwise
More stubborn than Drannith's walls.
No human eyes have ever witnessed the birth of an apex monster.

"Inner peace is wonderful, and worth striving for. Outer peace is much less important."
—Taelya, Lavabrink pyromage
All they found in the hunter's camp were tiny paw prints and a lot of blood.
"From this day forward, we confront this world together, lifting each other up."
"Being all-knowing is a matter of remembering which things it is crucial to forget."

"Strike those abominations down. Let their names rot with their remains."
—General Kudro
A crackling roar is the last sound many hunters hear.
"I study bone because that's where truth dwells. One monster knucklebone is wiser than all that damp meat in your head."
The bounty on its head is as old as Skysail, but no one has ever tried to collect.
Fear is its habitat, sanity its prey.
She wept, not from perfect understanding, but from serene gratitude.
Size of a pixie, rage of a hellkite.
As Narset struggled to meditate, tiny dragonlings spiraled around her, conjuring thoughts of ancient clans.

"I defy this world to try our defenses now. Send pterons and skycats. Send Vadrok!"
—Janae, Coppercoat architect
Considering the zealous armies, vile poachers, and titanic monsters, it's always wise to keep one eye on the horizon.
"We are each other's shadow, fleeing yet always present."
She was born unable to walk. Through the *eludha*, she was able to fly.

"You're little now, yes, but one day your footsteps will make mountains tremble."
—Gustin, wildbonder
The call of the wild is rarely a solo.
Crystals nestle in the roots of Indatha's helica trees as if being nurtured by their embrace.
The dark of night never truly falls on Ketria, where abundant crystals bathe the land in their glow.
As it twists, so does all life around it.
The vegetation in Raugrin is dull, but that only makes the towering crystal structures gleam brighter.
The same crystals that root deep enough to pierce Savai's catacombs also soar high enough to change its weather.

"Sleep now, you big brute."
—Kelsien, the Plague

"Stop trying to pierce the hide. Hit where it's softest: ankle, sole, hamstring."
—Master Hunter Chevill
From the fertile muck of Zagoth, everything—animal, botanical, and crystalline—grows with rugged beauty.
There is a sanctuary that reveals itself only to those graced by the *eludha*—the mystical connection between bonder and monster.

"It's not hard to grasp that this land does not belong to us."
—Gavi, nest waren

"These lowlands were formed thousands of years ago by behemoth Indath—its final footsteps before vanishing into the sea."
—*Tales of the Ozolith*
Nowhere on Ikoria are monsters more integral to the landscape than Ketria, where the river itself will stand up and roar.
Raugrin meets the sea with jaws wide, its coast spiked with teeth of crystal and granite.
Broad prairies feed the human sanctuary of Drannith and conceal a network of caverns where giant cats make their dens.
Hunters in the primeval wetlands become fluent in reading the ripples to tell when to pursue and when to flee.
"Our sanctuaries must be beacons of reason and calm or else they will fall."

"Nature is more merciless than any hunter I've ever known."
—Zai, nightsquad captain

"And then the shadow took living form, and the shadow devoured the man whole—body, mind, and soul."
—*Tales of the Ozolith*
As it twists, so does all life around it.
"Talk later. Run now!"

"Day 1: These fox pups have really taken to me.
"Day 4: Big. So big. Need additional security."
—Jonald, mission naturalist, research notes

"It's them or us."
—General Kudro
The two looked at each other, and neither fled. "I see," the soldier murmured. "We're both just fighting for survival out here, aren't we?"
Size of a pixie, rage of a hellkite.
Athreos cares little for the other gods' conflict with mortals. He is concerned only with safe passage for the dead.
Even when many of the soldiers who guarded Akros were called away, its safety was never in doubt.
"Nyx may belong to the gods, but the skies of Theros are ours."
"It is done." —Elspeth
"In our war Heliod gave mortals some favor, yet other times he withheld aid. Are we still no more than game pieces to him?" —Polyxene the Doubter
"Even from miles away, I could see our eagles circling. That's when I gave the command to pick up the pace. I knew we were needed at home." —Kanlos, Akroan captain
It is the soul of a philosopher who died of starvation contemplating the universe.
Drink deep, and be restored.
Not all shields are forged of iron or bronze.
Go forth with honor, return with glory.
"The stars belong in the night sky. This is our world, and we are our own masters."
The gods are fascinated by innocence, perhaps because it's a quality they themselves lack.

After the Battle of Pharagax Bridge, the Champion spent many months among the leonin of Oreskos. She found that they were quick to take offense, not because they were thin-skinned, but because they were always eager for a fight. —The Theriad
"A tiny flame is enough to dispel the night." —Elspeth
Pray her spear reaches you first. Her griffin is less kind.
Ephara taught some mortals to feel every vein in marble as though it flows with their own blood.
They are trained from hatching to deliver aid where it is needed most.
"Death is tyranny. Like all tyranny, it must be opposed."
"That is not the voice of the wind singing on the stones." —Callaphe the mariner
The physical pain was nothing compared to the agony in his mind.
Choices are rarely as simple as they seem.
Honesty is the first casualty of war.
"Knowledge is cruel. It will break your heart and test your allegiances. Are you certain you want this curse?"
Drink deep, and your thoughts will flow freely.
"I will match Thassa drop for drop and show a god what true power is." —Kiora
"You wish to learn of Nyx? Very well." —Phenax, god of deception
"Mortal strength, like mortal hope, is so easily crushed." —Thassa, god of the sea
Ideas, not stones, form the true foundation of Meletis.
"I want one." —Kiora
An offering to the sea brings an insight from the stars.
Kruphix hid the most dire prophecies about humankind where humans would never find them and tritons wouldn't care to read them.
When mortals claim there are places Thassa cannot reach, the sea god laughs.
The sailor had never seen a god before. Now she had gazed upon Thassa. Shortly she would see Athreos, and then she would meet Erebos.
The tritons broke the surface, and the Nyxborn broke ranks.
"Who will miss you, drywalker? A wife? A child? Perhaps they will blame the sea for your fate, and teach future generations to stay far away from it."
Once she sang sailors to their doom. Now she leads them to glory.
Stand against the crash of the river's rapids and you will know the power of the naiads.
Erebos's minions hunt the Returned and warn those who consider the same folly.
"My adopted children are loved no less." —Pharika, god of affliction
In desperation the soldier prayed to Phenax, begging for the power to cheat the gorgon's gaze.
"I take no pleasure in your suffering, but it is necessary. Once you accept your fate you'll find eternity more tolerable."
Crippling fear precedes it. A foul stench accompanies it. Death follows in its wake.
Phenax offers the hope of life, while Pharika grants the solace of death. Between them stands Erebos, who promises nothing but eternity.
"We gave the gods the power to war against us. It is time we took that power back."
It's common practice among minotaurs to collect the heads of their victims as trophies. Sometimes the trophies prove more than ornamental.
Drink deep, and death will recoil from you.
Occasionally the living wander to the Rivers, but the wardens of Athreos ensure that only the dead pass.
Any pleasure, when taken to excess, becomes torment. It's a formula that demons have perfected.
"To think some believe it peaceful to die in one's sleep." —Ashiok, Nightmare Weaver
A balm or a poison depending on how it is administered, and to whom.
The serpents' dens built into statues of Pharika serve not only to consecrate her temples, but as a hidden line of defense.
The flesh is dead and the life forgotten, but old habits persist.
A mask forged to avenge a death forgotten.

The hulk rose from the sea and loomed over the Champion. Pinned beneath the twisting, rotted planks of wood was the body of Kaliaros, the helmsman of her former crew, and beside him the captain, Photine. —The Theriad
"Only a fool takes Phenax at his word. What do you expect from a god born of lies and betrayal?" —Verenes, priest of Iroas
Leeches are sacred to followers of Pharika for drawing poison from a wound, but feared by everyone else for drawing blood from the flesh.
Some predators can sense fear in their prey, but the lamia is drawn to madness.
"Not all nightmares can be escaped by waking." —Ashiok, Nightmare Weaver
Elspeth feared that her trespass into Nyx would not go unanswered.
The enemies' shields are the first to shatter, and their battle line is never far behind.
To hold the heavens from the earth is no curse, but a titanic responsibility.
Deathbellow Canyon is home to minotaurs and many other creatures that share a love for the taste of human flesh.
"The anger that festers inside this one is contagious." —Anthousa of Setessa
Iroas and Mogis are as different in appearance as they are in personality.
Xenagos reveled while Theros burned.
A minotaur does not distinguish between human, satyr, and triton. They are all meat.
Drink deep, and find your vengeance fulfilled.
Purphoros shaped the oreads out of stray coals from his forge.
The cyclops had learned to never eat a shepherd. Instead he gently flung the "pit" aside to grow a new flock.
"Information is a powerful weapon." —Cymede, queen of Akros
"I fight for Keranos and for mortals. I see no contradiction."
The ancient dragon Thraxes sleeps in Purphoros's sacred peak. When he stirs in dreams, so does the mountain.

The Champion and her companions marched through the night, but the battle was over before they arrived. In the middle of the carnage sat a solitary minotaur, lost in what seemed to the Champion to be thought. —The Theriad
Fire to destroy. Fire to create.
"Embrace every moment, for it could be your last." —Xenagos, god of revels
"Xenagos has become what he once despised: a tyrant and an oppressor."
The runes seem to come alive as it moves, rippling like slow flames across its scales.
Sparks from Purphoros's forge fill the belly of every dragon.
"The most brilliant stars are not born of Nyx." —Rhexenor, Akroan flamespeaker
Setessan warriors of Bassara Tower are known for their guerrilla tactics and skill with the bow. Interlopers into the Nessian Wood do not get far.
"The gods think of us as insects. Perhaps there is wisdom in that." —Perisophia the philosopher
"I refuse to let the folly of mortals endanger the home I made for them."
The emotional echoes of dryad gatherings attract lost souls.
Drink deep, and know the path to the heart of the wilds.
"It is not yours to hunt, mortal. Be content with its beauty alone." —Nylea, god of the hunt
The temptation to take the ox's golden hide is as irresistible as it is fatal.
Travelers' tales claim that hydras bite off their own heads to make themselves deadlier.
The anger of the gods multiplied in Nyx, and the land awoke in dark echoes of their rage.
The horizon is tantalizing in both its uncertainty and its potential.
Commerce is always the basis for peace.
Nature protects its own.
"I do not know if the forest was different after they passed. But I know I was." —Ianthe, Setessan hunter
"Flesh and bone or star and shadow. It makes no difference to my club."
The renowned warchiefs of Pheres Band fight with the might of minotaurs and the sagacity of sphinxes.
Hunger makes a leucrocota dangerous. A full belly makes it angry and dangerous.
"You think your weaving as beautiful as mine? Let me show you the true meaning of the craft."
"Listen to my song, and you need never forge a golden mask to return to me."
"Some of my kin dance for themselves, without greater purpose. Nylea gives me purpose, and with it strength."
At the Akroan gates, hoplites revived the tactics of Kytheon Iora's infamous irregulars.
"Xenagos has fallen, and the world grows dark without him. What can ever fill that darkness but our rage?" —Guruthes, disciple of Xenagos
Coins of the Underworld are shaped from clay funerary masks.
From a distance the weapons look pristine, but in fact they are tarnished and dented, each as unique as the champion who carried it to battle.
The greatest heroes are the first to stand, the first to take up arms, and the first to meet the enemy.
In Akros, the penalty for running from battle is one night's stay in the Deserter's Quarters.
Blessed by the gods. Coveted by mortals. Beholden to neither.
Heroes act without thought of glory or reward. Accolades are a consequence, not a goal.
Five rivers encircle Theros, flowing with waters more ancient than the world itself.
"He hasn't returned to the Cloud Forest. But I can still sense his calming presence." —Zaliki of Naya
"When one of us prospers, the pride prospers." —Jazal Goldmane
With skill and strength honed upon the prairie, Naxtil won his battles high above it.
"Fine soldiers guarded the northern front. They waited for two-legged foes and left the skies unheeded." —General Avitora
Some angels protect the meek and innocent. Others seek out and smite evil wherever it lurks.
"I carry the light of truth. Do not pity those it blinds, for they never had eyes to see."
"They say only the good die young. Obviously, you are one of the exceptions." —Delrobah, cleric of Ivora Gate
Each crusader bonds with a griffin fledgling while still a child, and the two grow up as siblings.
"No doubt the arbiters would put you away, after all the documents are signed. But I will have justice now." —Alovnek, Boros guildmage
The vanguard is skilled at waging war alone. The enemy is often defeated before its reinforcements reach the front.
"Our law prohibits capital punishment. We believe even the gravest offenders have the chance to redeem themselves." —Torian Sha, soul warden
"Little moth, fluttering bright, What luck will you bring tonight?" —Benalish children's rhyme
"Born under the sun, the first child will seek the foundation of honor and be fortified by its righteousness." —Codex of the Constellari
Together the soldiers were like a golden blade, cutting down their enemies and scarring the darkness.
"Any fool can pick up a sword and charge into battle. To emerge alive at the end, that is a gift that comes from leadership and experience."
"Impossible! How could they overwhelm us? We had barricades, war elephants, . . . and they were barely a tenth of our number!" —General Avitora
"The southern fortress taken by invaders? Heh, sure . . . when elephants fly." —Brezard Skeinbow, captain of the guard
For the first time in his life, Grakk felt a little warm and fuzzy inside.
"I'm not nearly as bothered by being outnumbered as I am by their foul stench."
With one flap of her wings, the angel beat back the fires of war.
Perfect justice in service of a perfect will.
"The walls of the wicked will fall before us. Ready the siege engines. We proceed to war!" —General Avitora
"Take a quiet moment to reflect on your sins." —Cleph, Order of Redeemed Souls
"In the wild, white fur like mine is an aberration. We lack natural camouflage, but the inability to hide encourages other strengths." —Ajani Goldmane
"A relic donation is suggested." "The suggestion is mandatory." —Temple signs
"At summer's end, the pegasus herd stampedes across the sky. Their silent footfalls taunt the clouds and bid the rains to come." —Stormfront fable
A blazing sun that never sets.
If they succeed in their holy work, their order will vanish into welcome obscurity, for there will be no more souls to redeem.
"Let nothing take away from the purity of swords clashing or of arrows taking flight toward the breast of evil."
Farmers typically keep their flocks at thirteen sheep—one to distract the griffins while they take the other twelve to market.
Some mages do their best work in solitude. Others do their best work creating it.
"Wind is forceful, yet ephemeral. It can knock a dragon out of the sky, yet pass through the smallest crack unhindered." —Jestus Dreya, Of Elements and Eternity

"The ground polluted floats with human gore, And human carnage taints the dreadful shore Fly swift the dangerous coast: let every ear Be stopp'd against the song! 'tis death to hear!" —Homer, The Odyssey, trans. Pope
Creatures displaced from time still turn up every year, stranded by the temporal disaster that once swept across Dominaria.
More so than "storm" or "pirate," "drake" is the word a sailor least wants to hear.
"It's hard to say which is more satisfying: the search for that missing piece or fitting that piece into place." —Evo Ragus
The shapeshifter mimics with a twin's esteem and a mirror's cruelty.
"The sky teems with just as much life as the forest or the deep seas." —Hadi Kasten, Calla Dale naturalist
"'That was a narrow escape!' said Alice, a good deal frightened at the sudden change, but very glad to find herself still in existence." —Lewis Carroll, Alice's Adventures in Wonderland
"Your downfall was not your ignorance, your weakness, or your hubris, but your warm blood." —Heidar, Rimewind master
Two eyes to see what could be, two eyes to see what will.
Like most giant monsters villagers worship as gods, it proves a fickle master.
"You should try to clear your mind of idle thoughts. And if you can't, I will."
"Brute force can sometimes kick down a locked door, but knowledge is a skeleton key."
The fatal flaw in every plan is the assumption that you know more than your enemy.
Once common in the Kapsho Seas, merfolk were hunted almost to extinction. They survived those dark days and emerged calculating and determined to endure.
"Be like the sea: flow around that which is unmovable; for everything else, crash into it unrelentingly."
"The mind: a great weapon and an even greater weakness." —Jace Beleren
Masters of the arcane savor a delicious irony. Their study of deep and complex arcana leads to such a simple end: the ability to say merely yes or no.
As insubstantial as fear, and as dangerous.
"Your strategy is marvelous. I've just made a few minor adjustments." —Veris, watcher of Indi Keep
I've learned how to disable wards, pick locks, and decode the Agaran language—all before even reading the scroll!
"I give them dreams so wondrous that they hesitate to return to the world of the conscious." —Garild, merfolk mage
"Optimists see the world as they wish it to be. Pessimists see the world as it is. Must these roles be mutually exclusive?" —Evo Ragus
Genius is overrated, especially when it's someone else's.
He was left with just enough memory to understand what he had lost.
"You're trespassing in my reality. Ask permission next time." —Simun the Quiet
"I welcome it. The pasture is cleared of weeds and the wolves are frozen solid." —Lumi, goatherd
"This creature has innate perceptiveness. It knows when to rise and when to vanish into the tides." —Jestus Dreya, Of Elements and Eternity
"This is how wars are won—not with armies of soldiers but with a single knife blade, artfully placed." —Yurin, royal assassin
"Poor little sun-dweller out past curfew. And to think, you might have survived if it wasn't so close to suppertime."
The Crimson Throne may be empty, but its coffers are full.
"The underclass often forget that they are not tenants, or servants, but property."
Zombies are the perfect marshland fighters—they don't need to breathe and they don't care what they step in.
A vampire enacts vengeance on the entire world, claiming her debt two tiny pinpricks at a time.
The power of the fens sleeps lightly, and always awakens hungry.
"It is a rough road that leads to the heights of greatness." —Seneca, Epistles, trans. Gummere
There are few ways to escape the deathmark: bargaining with a demon, washing in the fabled waters of youth, and of course, death.
The locks on the cages of the damned are opened with keys of marrow, sinew, and blood.
The wise always keep an ear open to the whispers of power.
The armies of the dead always report well rested.
The void is without substance but cuts like steel.
"Don't worry. I'm not going to deprive you of all your secrets. Just your most precious one." —Liliana Vess
Death in form and function.
Only a thin layer of dirt separates civilization from an undead apocalypse.
Villagers cloaked the town in magical silence, but their ears still bled.
"This might hurt less if you don't fight so hard. But I doubt it."
"The finest minions know what I need without me ever saying a thing." —Liliana Vess
Not every thought is a good one.
In life, the nantuko study nature by revering it. In death, they study nature by disemboweling it.
"My dreams darkened and seeped into my waking hours. Spellcraft and nightmare merged to create this monstrosity." —Sunniva, witch of Holm Hollow
"There is one hour of the night even we do not watch." —Sedva, captain of the watch
The dread gases didn't kill Farbid. But as he lay in the muck, miserable and helpless, watching ghouls and rats advance on him, he wished they had.
Though you may see the same bones, you'll never see the same skeleton twice.
"Death is no excuse for disobedience." —Liliana Vess
Zombies have one speed: shamble.
An assassin is a king's most trusted courier, ensuring his messages are heard by even the most unwilling recipients.
Little agonies pave the way to greater power.
"You can take the fight out of nearly any creature if you know where its soft spot is." —Guttor, flesh-warper
"Born under the moon, the second child will stumble on temptation and seek power in the dark places of the heart." —Codex of the Constellari
In matters of life and death, he trusts his gut.
"Rage courses in every heart, yearning to betray its rational prison." —Sarkhan Vol
When a dragon attacks, there are no bystanders.
The storms of the wastelands form quickly and hit hard. Few have anything to do with rain.
They take a blood oath to die in battle. So far none have failed to fulfill the promise.
"A single drop of blood draws their attention, then they strip your bones clean before you have time to die." —Jamias, hermit of Telfer Peak
"We'll scale these cliffs, traverse Brittle Bridge, and then fight our way down the volcanic slopes on the other side." "Isn't the shortest route through the canyon?" "Yes." "So shouldn't we—" "No."
"Her mind is an incredible mix of emotion and power. Even if I could grasp it, I couldn't hold it for long." —Jace Beleren, on Chandra Nalaar
"I've lit most everything on fire—trees, rocks, even the water. Now it's time to burn the clouds."
The end of the world rarely comes quietly.
"Fire. Air. Water. These elements spread, filling in the spaces they are not. But earth is implacable like a sullen child." —Jestus Dreya, Of Elements and Eternity
Flurk's crude goblin language didn't differentiate between "I bring the flame" and "I am the flame."
"I had hoped to instill in it the loyalty of a guard dog, but with fire's power comes its unpredictability." —Maggath, Sardian elementalist
"Elemental fire shimmers with rose hues and, unlike terrestrial blazes, smolders long after it's extinguished." —Jestus Dreya, Of Elements and Eternity
Sometimes the cannoneer must become the cannonball.
"The enemy is getting too close! Quick! Inflate the toad!"
"We are goblinkind, heirs to the mountain empires of chieftains past. Rest is death to us, and arson is our call to war."
Once he'd worked out which end of the thing was sharp, he was promoted to guard duty.

From the heart of the mountain into the heart of the mage.
It's fun. He doesn't need another reason.
"What am I looking at? Ashes, dead man."
The Multiverse is filled with limitless power just waiting for someone to reach out and seize it.

"I'm not indecisive. I just don't like to limit my options." —Maxti, pyromancer
Lightning reflexes, thunderous might.

He will carve out a legend for himself with his own two hands.

"Nature is a mutable cloud which is always and never the same." —Ralph Waldo Emerson, Essays
"The gods used their feathers to paint all the colors of the world." —Yare-Tiva, warden of Gramur forest

All seeds share a common bond, calling to each other across infinity.
She grants knowledge of the ways to traverse the forest's invisible connections.

She wears the talismans of every creature she can evoke.

"He has learned much in his long years. And unlike selfish humans, he's willing to share." —Garruk Wildspeaker

Bone, stone . . . both taste the same to a hungry basilisk.

One bone broken for every twig snapped underfoot. —Llanowar penalty for trespassing
"Nature does not need adornment." —Garruk Wildspeaker
Snail shell, fern, tornado—the world connects all things in form.

When nature calls, run.
"The desire for its magic horn inspires such bloodthirsty greed that all who see the unicorn will kill to possess it." —Dionus, elvish archdruid

Anywhere else, colossal. In the forests of Yavimaya, commonplace.
If taken, it cuts the hand that clutches it. If given, it heals the hand that holds it.

"Please, honored friend, take it with my compliments. I insist."

For the first time in his life, Grakk felt a little warm and fuzzy inside.
"They knew Bantau was lost when, to hide the pearl he had found on the beach, he swallowed it—and soon grew wings." —Hakim, Loreweaver

"Our soldiers are blessed with lizard scales as hard and cold as steel." —Sidar Jabari

"Command is the act of balancing on a vine and convincing others that it is firm ground." —Sidar Jabari

"Wear the falcon's feathers in your hair— be fast as the falcon, bright as the Sun." —"Rise on Wings," Zhalfirin song

"Useful . . . if you can find it." —Pashad ibn Asim, Suq'Ata trader

"Tell me . . . have you ever sung the Song of Blood?" —Purraj of Urborg

Want all, lose all. —Zhalfirin aphorism
"Magic's only part of it, my friend. Diet does the rest." —Pashad ibn Asim, Suq'Ata trader
Storyteller: By my hand in the fire, this story is a tale of power. Listeners: May it give you strength.
"In the forest, fires light the sky as black clouds unfold their weight." —"Love Song of Night and Day"
They talk a good fight.

"Inhale. Kill. Exhale."
When you've been chased by a dragon, you run from every lizard. —Suq'Ata saying

"Execution awaits the dissenter." —Kasib ibn Naji, Letters

Speed and fire are always a deadly combination.

"The efreet is a striding storm with a voice that crackles like fire." —Qhattib, Vizier of Amiqat
"Defiantly, the young cyclops popped the brushwagg into his mouth. His cheeks suddenly puffed, his eye bulged, and he was forced to agree with his elder." —Afari, Tales
"In the Mwonvuli you must divide your attention between what hangs overhead and what lies underfoot." —Sidar Jabari
Love is like a rhino, short-sighted and hasty; if it cannot find a way, it will make a way. —Femeref adage
Thus does nature assert herself.

". . . and when the farmer awoke the next morning, all the seeds from his field were once again in their sacks." —Afari, Tales
"They say a Zhalfirin archer can split the eye of a griffin. Nonsense, of course: they have no faith to guide their darts." —Nuru, Femeref archer

Five hundred years to grow—barely a minute to eat.
"I hate insects of every sort. The only mercy is that they are generally small." —Mwani, Mtenda goatherd
Hyenas laughing—what's the joke? —Femeref phrase meaning "that's not funny"
Leave no mouth agape, no stomach unfilled. —Granger Guild maxim
"What need have I for cavalry when I can have horse and rider both in one?" —Jolrael
Broad as a baobab—and about as smart.
"Be like the meerkat, my daughters: ever vigilant, true to your own, and wary of strangers." —Nabil Alamat, Suq'Ata merchant
Better a fierce thunderhead than a sky filled with locusts.
No two see the same Maro.
"The lion drank that lake right up! In thanks, he gave Siti the power to speak with lions and make them leave the goats alone." —Afari, Tales
"The few of us who survived were denied entry to our camp for two days—so like the pox were the marks we bore." —Travelogue of Najat
"I've never heard growth before." —Gowon, Femeref herder
"Death is not a debt I am yet willing to pay." —Purraj of Urborg
Better to fight the sand for a few hours than to sleep beneath it forever. —Suq'Ata truism

"If magic is your crutch, cast it aside and learn to walk without it." —Teferi
In the Jamuraan jungles, there is often no separating beauty from danger.

"An ancient court mage unified the houses into guilds to serve Zhalfir above their own interests. Even during the civil war, the guilds stood together, a testament to the wisdom of Teferi." —Afari, Tales
"After the storm, I found a sea turtle dying on the sands, a blade of grass driven through its shell." —Travelogue of Najat
Victim of the two-toed faerie —Suq'Ata expression meaning "broken"
"To pass through the jungle: silence, courtesy, ferocity, as the occasion demands." —Kamau, "Proper Passage"
"Much can be learned from the bees about dying for a cause." —Asmira, Holy Avenger
"Enchant me with your tale-telling. Tell about Tree, Grass, River, and Wind. / Tell why Truth must fight with Falsehood, and why Truth will always win." —"Love Song of Night and Day"

Sometimes the wise ones wove their magic into living plants; as the plant grew, so grew the magic.
"I will tell my father's stories . . . . How the elephants trampled the leopard cub, and its father, though he knew, killed nine goats instead." —"Love Song of Night and Day"
"Aselbo soon had the rhino eating from his palm and the snake waiting at his heels." —Afari, Tales
"Omens lie in this early harvest's fruit." —Asmira, Holy Avenger
"In all my years I've only met one mage who successfully trapped a djinn—and none who tried and failed." —Talibah, embermage
"It's filthy work, planting them." —Kifimbo, Shadow Guildmage
"Life is a resource that should belong only to the strong." —Shauku, Endbringer
The fire breathes while the air burns.
Life and death are two faces of the same coin.
"Hmmm—midnight snack."
"Our guardian levies a tax on all traders. Wise travelers pay with a minimum of fuss." —Qhattib, Vizier of Amiqat
Like some foul herdbeast, it grazes on the dead.
"The hazerider danced in the thunderstorm and sang to its music." —Afari, Tales
"You eat plants; I eat plants. You eat beasts; I eat you." —Drulvurg, troll king
"Only a gargoyle would take such delight in a thunderstorm." —Qhattib, Vizier of Amiqat
Only those who have nothing have nothing to fear.
"How ironic that the greatest forge of civilization is battle." —Mangara
"Her beauty was the beauty of the Sun at midday, deadly to those who underestimated her strength." —Azeworai, "Kenechi's Dream"
From you to me, so me to you. —Femeref children's taunt
"Sorry I burned down your village. Here's some gold."
In the eastern reaches of Jamuraa are arrangements of massive stones. No one knows their origins—for certain.
"Frozen, we watched the funnel pluck up three of the goats—pook! pook! pook!—before we ran for the wadi." —Travelogue of Najat
It's good to know more about your enemy's fate than your enemy does.

Time is the one shackle you can't break. —Zhalfirin aphorism
"Like Day from Night, / I'll live my life apart from you, just glimpsing you across the sky, / because you cannot change, my dear, and nor can I." —"Love Song of Night and Day"
"Water is like breathing—necessary for life." —Asmira, Holy Avenger
Even wurms start out small.
Watching the windreaper —Zhalfirin phrase meaning "daydreaming"
"I'll capture gentle zebras / for your steeds and fill the stable with every kind of unicorn." —"Love Song of Night and Day"
Trade to trade, not to keep. —Suq'Ata motto

"Eternal life or your money back." —Unnamed Suq'Ata merchant, deceased

Slow and heavy swings the club.
